Propose-Test-Release

Posted on 2020-11-23 Edited on 2025-08-20

Let \((\mathcal{X}, d)\) be a metric space and \(q : \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) be a function defined on \(\mathcal{X}\). The metric \(d: \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) takes only integer values. For an \(x \in \mathcal{X}\), it neighbors an \(x' \in \mathcal{X}\), termed \(x \sim x'\), if \(d(x, x') = 1\).

Further, define the global sensitivity \(\Delta\) of \(q\) as: \[ \Delta \doteq \max_{x \sim x' } | q(x) - q(x') | \]

The Laplace mechanism \(M\) of \(q\) adds random noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\Delta}{\varepsilon})\) to the output of \(q\): \[ M(x) \doteq q(x) + N \]

where \(\mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\Delta}{\varepsilon})\) is the Laplacian distribution with parameter \(\frac{\Delta}{\varepsilon}\). It guarantees that if \(x \sim x'\), the output distributions of \(M(x)\) and \(M(x')\) are indistinguishable in the sense that for all \(S \subset \mathbb{R}\), s.t. \(S\) is measurable, it holds that \[ \Pr[ M(x) \in S] \in [ e^{ - \varepsilon }, e^{ \varepsilon } ] \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \in S] \]

The value of \(\Delta\) could be large and is independent of an \(x \in \mathcal{X}\). We would like to investigate the possibility of adding a smaller noise than \(\mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\Delta}{\varepsilon})\).

For a fixed \(x\), we can define the local sensitivity with respect to \(x\) as \[ \delta(x) \doteq \max_{x' \sim x} | q(x) - q(x') |. \]

Here the maximum is over the neighbors of a fixed \(x\). The value between \(\Delta\) and \(\delta(x)\) is quite different.

Example. Let * \(\mathcal{X} \doteq [0, 100]^3\).
* \(d(x, x')\doteq \#\text{ different values between } x \text{ and } x'\). * \(q(x) \doteq \min_{1 \le i < j \le 3} |x_i - x_j|\), where \(x_i\) is the \(i\)-dimension of \(x\).

Then for the point \(x = (0, 0, 0) \in [0, 100]^3\), if \(x' \sim x\), \(x'\) contains at least two zeros in some of its dimensions. Therefore, \(q(x') = 0\) and \(\delta(x) = 0\). But for \(x = (0, 0, 100)\), it has a neighbor \(x' = (0, 50, 100)\). Now \(q(x) = 0\) but \(q(x') = 50\). So \(\Delta \ge \delta(x) \ge 50\).

We are interested in whether adding smaller noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\delta(x) }{\varepsilon})\) to the output of \(q(x)\) would preserve privacy: \[ M(x) = q(x) + N. \]

However, this approach is not private. In the previous example, \((0, 0, 0)\) and \((0, 0, 100)\) are neighbors. But for the former we add noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(0)\) and for the latter we add noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(\frac{50}{\varepsilon})\). So the output distributions of them are very different and this would violate privacy protection.

Perhaps, we should propose some fixed parameter \(\beta > 0\) (which could be much smaller than \(\Delta\)), and add a noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\beta}{\varepsilon})\) for whatever \(x \in \mathcal{X}\). For a pair of neighboring \(x, x'\), when \(|q(x) - q(x')| \le \beta\), then the distributions of \(q(x) + N\) and \(q(x') + N\) are indeed \((\varepsilon, 0)\) indistinguishable. The only concern is for the case where \(|q(x) - q(x')| > \beta\) and adding a noise \(N \sim \mathbb{Lap}(\frac{\beta}{\varepsilon})\) fails to protect the privacy.

One simple remedy is simply to refuse to output \(q(x) + N\) (or \(q(x) + N'\)). This should be done in a differentially private manner. Let \[ \{ y \in \mathcal{X} : \delta(y) > \beta \} \]

be the set of points with local sensitivity greater than \(\beta\). For a fixed \(x\), define \(d(x, \{ y : \delta(y) > \beta \})\) be its distance to the set. It follows that for \(x \sim x'\), \[ |d(x, \{ y \in \mathcal{X} : \delta(y) > \beta \}) - d(x', \{ y \in \mathcal{X} : \delta(y) > \beta \})| \le 1. \]

This motivates the following propose-test-release algorithm.

  1. Propose a bound \(\beta\) on local sensitivity.
  2. Compute \(\hat d \doteq d(x, \{ y \in \mathcal{X} : \delta(y) > \beta \}) + \mathbb{Lap}(1 / \varepsilon)\).
  3. If \(\hat d \le \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \ln \frac{1}{\gamma}\) then
    \(\qquad\) output \(\bot\).
  4. Else
    \(\qquad\) output \(q(x) + \mathbb{Lap}(\beta / \varepsilon)\).

Theorem. The algorithm is \((2\varepsilon, \gamma / 2)\) differentially private.

Proof.

First observe that for two neighboring \(x, x'\), their probabilities of outputting \(\bot\) are similar. \[ \Pr[ M(x) = \bot ] \le e^{ \varepsilon} \cdot \Pr[ M(x') = \bot ] \\ \Pr[ M(x) \neq \bot ] \le e^{ \varepsilon} \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \neq \bot ] \]

Now consider a measurable set \(S \subset \mathbb{R}\). \(M(x) \in S\) is only possible when \(\hat d > \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \ln \frac{1}{\gamma}\):
\[ \begin{aligned} \Pr[M(x) \in S] &= \Pr[ M(x) \in S \mid M(x) \neq \bot ] \cdot \Pr[ M(x) \neq \bot] \end{aligned} \]

We consider two cases.

  • Case 1. When \(\delta(x) > \beta\), then \(d(x, \{ y \in \mathcal{X} : \delta(y) > \beta \}) = 0\). It follows that \[ \Pr[M(x) \in S] \le \Pr[M(x) \neq \bot ] \le \frac{\gamma}{2} \]

  • Case 2. When \(\delta(x) \le \beta\), it holds that \(|q(x) - q(x') |\le \beta\) and \[ \Pr[ M(x) \in S \mid M(x) \neq \bot ] \le e^\varepsilon \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \in S \mid M(x') \neq \bot ] \] Therefore, \[ \begin{aligned} \Pr[M(x) \in S] &= \Pr[ M(x) \in S \mid M(x) \neq \bot ] \cdot \Pr[ M(x) \neq \bot] \\ &\le \Pr[ M(x) \in S \mid M(x) \neq \bot ] \cdot e^\varepsilon \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \neq \bot] \\ &\le e^\varepsilon \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \in S \mid M(x') \neq \bot ] \cdot e^\varepsilon \cdot \Pr[ M(x') \neq \bot] \\ &= e^{2\varepsilon} \Pr[ M(x') \in S]. \end{aligned} \]

\(\blacksquare\)

Reference

[1] S. Vadhan, “The Complexity of Differential Privacy,” in Tutorials on the Foundations of Cryptography, Y. Lindell, Ed. Cham: Springer International Publishing, 2017, pp. 347–450.

PAC Learning From Countable Hypothesis Family

Posted on 2020-11-19 Edited on 2021-03-26

We generalize the PAC learning problem of finding an hypothesis from a finite hypothesis family to the one from a countable hypothesis family.

Problem Setting

  1. X:\mathcal{X}:X: the input space.

  2. Y≐{−1,1}:\mathcal{Y} \doteq \{-1, 1\}:Y≐{−1,1}: the output space.

  3. Z≐X×Y:\mathcal{Z} \doteq \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}:Z≐X×Y: the product space of X\mathcal{X}X and Y\mathcal{Y}Y.

  4. D:\mathcal{D}:D: an unknown distribution defined on X×Y\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}X×Y.

  5. H:\mathcal{H}:H: an countable family of hypothesis, s.t., each h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H is a function from X\mathcal{X}X to Y\mathcal{Y}Y.

  6. ℓ:Y×Y→[0,1]\ell: \mathcal{Y} \times \mathcal{Y} \rightarrow [0, 1]ℓ:Y×Y→[0,1], a loss function that takes two points in Y\mathcal{Y}Y and outputs a value between 000 and 111.

  7. LD(h):L_\mathcal{D} (h):LD​(h): the expected loss of a hypothesis hhh is defined as

    LD(h)=E(x,y)∼D[ℓ(h(x),y)]L_\mathcal{D} (h) = \mathbb{E}_{ (x, y) \sim \mathcal{D} } [ \ell( h(x), y) ] LD​(h)=E(x,y)∼D​[ℓ(h(x),y)]

    where (x,y)∼D(x, y) \sim \mathcal{D}(x,y)∼D implies that the pair (x,y)∈Z(x, y) \in \mathcal{Z}(x,y)∈Z is sampled according to the distribution D\mathcal{D}D.

  8. h∗≐arg⁡min⁡h∈HLD(h):h^* \doteq \arg\min_{h \in \mathcal{H} } L_\mathcal{D} (h):h∗≐argminh∈H​LD​(h): the hypothesis that minimize the expected loss.

  9. μh:\mu_h:μh​: an alias for LD(h)L_\mathcal{D} (h)LD​(h), when the distribution D\mathcal{D}D discussed in the context is unique.

  10. B(μh,ϵ)≐{r∈R:∣r−μh∣<ϵ}:B(\mu_h, \epsilon) \doteq \{ r \in \mathbb{R} : |r - \mu_h | < \epsilon \}:B(μh​,ϵ)≐{r∈R:∣r−μh​∣<ϵ}: an open ball, which is an open interval in R\mathbb{R}R centered at μh\mu_hμh​ with length 2ϵ2 \epsilon2ϵ, where ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0.

  11. S∼Dn:S \sim \mathcal{D}^n:S∼Dn: a set of nnn i.i.d samples drawn from D\mathcal{D}D, where n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+ is some positive integer. In particular, when S∼DnS \sim \mathcal{D}^nS∼Dn, it can be represented as

    S={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn):(xi,yi)∼D,∀i∈[n]}.S = \{ (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ..., (x_n, y_n) : (x_i, y_i) \sim \mathcal {D}, \forall i \in [n] \}. S={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​):(xi​,yi​)∼D,∀i∈[n]}.

    We also view SSS as a point in Zn\mathcal{Z}^nZn.

  12. LS(h)≐1∣S∣∑(x,y)∈Sℓ(h(x),y):L_{S}(h) \doteq \frac{1}{ |S| } \sum_{ (x, y) \in S } \ell( h(x) , y ) :LS​(h)≐∣S∣1​∑(x,y)∈S​ℓ(h(x),y): the empirical loss of a hypothesis hhh on a sample set SSS.

  13. Given a h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H, its restriction on C⊂X\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{X}C⊂X is a function hSh_ShS​ defined on SSS, such that

hC(x)=h(x),∀x∈Ch_\mathcal{C} (x) = h(x), \forall x \in \mathcal{C} hC​(x)=h(x),∀x∈C

  1. The restriction of H\mathcal{H}H on C\mathcal{C}C is the set of possible restriction of a function in H\mathcal{H}H to C\mathcal{C}C

    HC={hC:C→Y:h∈H} \mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C} = \{ h_\mathcal{C} : \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{Y} : h \in \mathcal{H} \} HC​={hC​:C→Y:h∈H}

    As Y={−1,+1}\mathcal{Y} = \{ -1, +1 \}Y={−1,+1}, the set of possible functions defined on C\mathcal{C}C is bounded by 2n2^{n}2n. Hence,

    ∣HC∣≤2n. |\mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C} | \le 2^{n}. ∣HC​∣≤2n.

  2. The growth function ΠH(n):N+→N+\Pi_{\mathcal{H} } (n): \mathbb{N}^+ \rightarrow \mathbb{N}^+ΠH​(n):N+→N+ of H\mathcal{H}H is defined as

ΠH(n)=max⁡C⊂X,∣C∣=n∣HC∣\Pi_{\mathcal{H} } (n) = \max_{\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{X}, |C| = n} | \mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C} | ΠH​(n)=C⊂X,∣C∣=nmax​∣HC​∣

Ideally, we would like to find h∗h^*h∗. The problem is difficult, as

  • The space X×Y\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}X×Y could be infinite.
  • The distribution D\mathcal{D}D is unknown.

To deal with the possibly infinite space X×Y\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{Y}X×Y and the unknown distribution D\mathcal{D}D, we investigate H\mathcal{H}H on a finite sample set SSS. Due to the randomness inherited in sampling SSS, we allow our solution to be approximate and to make error. For a given pair of parameters of ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 and δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, we relax the goal to designing an (ϵ,δ)(\epsilon, \delta)(ϵ,δ)-learning algorithm AAA that returns an h′h'h′, that is

  • ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate: μh′≤μh∗+ϵ\mu_{h'} \le \mu_{h^*} + \epsilonμh′​≤μh∗​+ϵ,
  • probably correct: AAA return an h′h'h′ that does not satisfies the above condition with probability at most δ\deltaδ.

Combined, AAA should return an ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate solution h′h'h′ with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ.

The Algorithm

An (ϵ,δ)(\epsilon, \delta)(ϵ,δ) approximate algorithm AAA

  1. Draw a set SSS of n=n =n= samples independently from D\mathcal{D}D.
  2. Return an h′h'h′ such that

h′=arg⁡min⁡h∈HLS(h) h' = \arg\min_{h \in \mathcal{H} } L_{S} (h) h′=argh∈Hmin​LS​(h)

A key result of the algorithm states that LS(h)L_S(h)LS​(h) is a good approximation of μh\mu_hμh​ for all h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H simultaneously.

Theorem. If n≥n \gen≥, then

Pr⁡S∼Dn[∃h∈H:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ/2)]≤δ \Pr_{S \sim \mathcal{D}^n } [ \exists h \in \mathcal{H} : L_S(h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2 ) ] \le \delta S∼DnPr​[∃h∈H:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ/2)]≤δ

An immediate corollary is that h′h'h′ is ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ:

μh′≤LS(h′)+ϵ2≤LS(h∗)+ϵ2≤μh∗+ϵ.\mu_{h'} \le L_S(h') + \frac{\epsilon}{2} \le L_S(h^*) + \frac{\epsilon}{2} \le \mu_{h^*} + \epsilon. μh′​≤LS​(h′)+2ϵ​≤LS​(h∗)+2ϵ​≤μh∗​+ϵ.

Proof of The Theorem

The proof relies on a technique called double sampling. Alongside with SSS, we create another sample set S′∼DnS' \sim \mathcal{D}^nS′∼Dn independently, termed the “ghost sample”. Let

S={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)}S = \{ (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ..., (x_n, y_n) \} S={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)}

and

S′={(x1′,y1′),(x2′,y2′),...,(xn′,yn′)}.S' = \{ (x_1', y_1'), (x_2', y_2'), ..., (x_n', y_n') \}. S′={(x1′​,y1′​),(x2′​,y2′​),...,(xn′​,yn′​)}.

Then, we define

  1. σ:\sigma:σ: a random swap that exchanges the iii-th (i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n]) element of SSS and S′S'S′ independently with probability 0.5. Call the resulting sample sets σS\sigma SσS and σS′\sigma S'σS′. Let σS[i]\sigma S[i]σS[i] (σS′[i]\sigma S'[i]σS′[i]) be the iii-th element of σS[i]\sigma S[i]σS[i] (σS′[i]\sigma S'[i]σS′[i]). So

    Pr⁡[σS[i]=(xi,yi)∧σS′[i]=(xi′,yi′)]=0.5Pr⁡[σS[i]=(xi′,yi′)∧σS′[i]=(xi,yi)]=0.5\Pr \left[ \sigma S [i] = (x_i, y_i) \wedge \sigma S'[i] = (x_i', y_i') \right] = 0.5 \\ \Pr \left[ \sigma S [i] = (x_i', y_i') \wedge \sigma S'[i] = (x_i, y_i) \right] = 0.5 Pr[σS[i]=(xi​,yi​)∧σS′[i]=(xi′​,yi′​)]=0.5Pr[σS[i]=(xi′​,yi′​)∧σS′[i]=(xi​,yi​)]=0.5

We use the gap of ∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣|L_{\sigma S} (h) - L_{\sigma S'} (h)|∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣ as a proxy of ∣LS(h)−μh∣|L_S(h) - \mu_h|∣LS​(h)−μh​∣. This enables us to focus on finite sets SSS and S′S'S′ without worrying about the infinite size of H\mathcal{H}H.

For convenience, we use Pr⁡S[⋅]\underset{S}{\Pr}[\cdot]SPr​[⋅] (Pr⁡S′[⋅]\underset{S'}{\Pr}[\cdot]S′Pr​[⋅]) as shorthand for Pr⁡S∼Dn[⋅]\underset{S \sim \mathcal{D}^n}{\Pr}[\cdot]S∼DnPr​[⋅] (Pr⁡S′∼Dn[⋅]\underset{S' \sim \mathcal{D}^n}{\Pr}[\cdot]S′∼DnPr​[⋅]). The road map of our proof is as follows.

Lemma 1.

Pr⁡S[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)]≤2max⁡S,S′∈ZnPr⁡σ[∃h:∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2] \Pr_{S}[ \exists h : L_S(h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) ] \le 2 \max_{S, S' \in \mathcal{Z}^n } \Pr_\sigma \left[ \exists h : |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] SPr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)]≤2S,S′∈Znmax​σPr​[∃h:∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]

On the left hand side of the inequality, the probability measures the event of a random set SSS sampling from D\mathcal{D}D. On the right hand side, we can pick a fixed pair of SSS and S′S'S′ that maximize

Pr⁡σ[∃h:∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2],\Pr_\sigma \left[ \exists h : |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right], σPr​[∃h:∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​],

and the probability measures the event of the random swap σ\sigmaσ. Fixing SSS and S′S'S′ significantly simplifies the structure of H\mathcal{H}H. By Hoeffding inequality and union bound, we will prove that

Lemma 2. For any fixed pair of S,S′∈ZnS, S' \in \mathcal{Z}^nS,S′∈Zn,

Pr⁡σ[∃h:∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2]≤2ΠH(2n)exp⁡(−n2ϵ22) \Pr_\sigma \left[ \exists h : |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] \le 2 \Pi_\mathcal{H} (2n) \exp( - \frac{n^2 \epsilon^2 }{2} ) σPr​[∃h:∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]≤2ΠH​(2n)exp(−2n2ϵ2​)

Proof of Lemma 1.

The proof of Lemma 1 consists of three steps.

Step 1

Pr⁡S[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)]≤2Pr⁡S,S′[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)∧LS′(h)∈B(μh,ϵ/2)]. \Pr_{S}[ \exists h : L_S(h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) ] \le 2 \Pr_{S , S'} [ \exists h : L_S (h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) \wedge L_{S'} (h) \in B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2) ]. SPr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)]≤2S,S′Pr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)∧LS′​(h)∈B(μh​,ϵ/2)].

Proof. By Hoeffding inequality, for a fixed h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H, when n≥2ϵ2ln⁡4n \ge \frac{2}{\epsilon^2} \ln 4n≥ϵ22​ln4

Pr⁡S′[LS′(h)∉B(μh,ϵ/2)]≤2exp⁡(−2n(ϵ2)2)=2exp⁡(−nϵ22)≤12 \Pr_{S'} [ L_{S'} (h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2) ] \le 2 \exp \left(- 2 n \left( \frac{\epsilon }{ 2 } \right)^2 \right) = 2 \exp \left( - \frac{n \epsilon^2}{2} \right) \le \frac{1}{2} S′Pr​[LS′​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ/2)]≤2exp(−2n(2ϵ​)2)=2exp(−2nϵ2​)≤21​

It follows that

Pr⁡S,S′[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)∧LS′(h)∈B(μh,ϵ/2)]≥12Pr⁡S[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)] \Pr_{S , S'} [ \exists h : L_S (h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) \wedge L_{S'} (h) \in B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2) ] \ge \frac{1}{2} \Pr_{S}[ \exists h : L_S(h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) ] S,S′Pr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)∧LS′​(h)∈B(μh​,ϵ/2)]≥21​SPr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)]

□\square□

Remark: Mathematically, I don’t know how to make prove this step rigorously. Suppose that for every i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], we know that the events EiE_iEi​ and FiF_iFi​ are measurable and independent. If Pr⁡[Fi]≥1/2\Pr[ F_i ] \ge 1 / 2Pr[Fi​]≥1/2, then Pr⁡[Ei∧Fi]≥1/2\Pr[ E_i \wedge F_i ] \ge 1 / 2Pr[Ei​∧Fi​]≥1/2. But, can we claim that

Pr⁡[∪(Ei∧Fi)]≥12Pr⁡[∪Ei]. \Pr[ \cup (E_i \wedge F_i) ] \ge \frac{1}{2} \Pr[ \cup E_i ]. Pr[∪(Ei​∧Fi​)]≥21​Pr[∪Ei​].

Step 2

Pr⁡S[∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)∧LS′(h)∈B(μh,ϵ/2)]≤Pr⁡S,S′[∃h:∣LS(h)−LS′(h)∣≥ϵ2] \Pr_{S} [ \exists h : L_S (h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) \wedge L_{S'} (h) \in B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2) ] \le \Pr_{S, S'} \left[ \exists h : |L_S (h) - L_{S'} (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] SPr​[∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)∧LS′​(h)∈B(μh​,ϵ/2)]≤S,S′Pr​[∃h:∣LS​(h)−LS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]

Proof. Observe that

{∃h:LS(h)∉B(μh,ϵ)∧LS′(h)∈B(μh,ϵ/2)}⊂{∃h:∣LS(h)−LS′(h)∣≥ϵ2}. \{ \exists h : L_S (h) \notin B(\mu_h, \epsilon ) \wedge L_{S'} (h) \in B(\mu_h, \epsilon / 2) \} \subset \left\{ \exists h : |L_S (h) - L_{S'} (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right\}. {∃h:LS​(h)∈/B(μh​,ϵ)∧LS′​(h)∈B(μh​,ϵ/2)}⊂{∃h:∣LS​(h)−LS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​}.

By monotonicity of probability, we finish the proof.

□\square□

Step 3

Pr⁡S,S′[∃h:∣LS(h)−LS′(h)∣≥ϵ2]≤max⁡S,S′∈ZnPr⁡σ[∃h:∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2] \Pr_{S, S' } \left[ \exists h : |L_S (h) - L_{S'} (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] \le \max_{S, S' \in \mathcal{Z}^n } \Pr_\sigma \left[ \exists h : |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] S,S′Pr​[∃h:∣LS​(h)−LS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]≤S,S′∈Znmax​σPr​[∃h:∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]

Proof. We claim that σS\sigma SσS and σS′\sigma S'σS′ have the same joint distribution as SSS and S′S'S′ (if S,S′∼DnS, S' \sim \mathcal{D}^nS,S′∼Dn). For points ∀Z,Z′∈Zn\forall Z, Z' \in \mathcal{Z}^n∀Z,Z′∈Zn, by symmetry, it holds that

Pr⁡S,S′[S=Z,S′=Z′]=Pr⁡S,S′,σ[σS=Z,σS′=Z′]\Pr_{S, S'} [ S = Z, S' = Z'] = \Pr_{S, S', \sigma} [ \sigma S = Z, \sigma S' = Z'] S,S′Pr​[S=Z,S′=Z′]=S,S′,σPr​[σS=Z,σS′=Z′]

The right hand side can be viewed as the successful probability of the following experiment:

  • Sample independently S∼DnS \sim \mathcal{D}^nS∼Dn and S′∼DnS' \sim \mathcal{D}^nS′∼Dn.
  • For each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], exchange the iii-th elements of SSS and S′S'S′ independently with probability 0.50.50.5.
  • After the random swap, σS=Z\sigma S = ZσS=Z and σS′=Z′\sigma S' = Z'σS′=Z′.

Now, ∀E⊂Z2n\forall \mathcal{E} \subset \mathcal{Z}^{2n}∀E⊂Z2n, it holds that

Pr⁡S,S′[(S,S′)∈E]=Pr⁡S,S′,σ[(σS,σS′)∈E]=ES,S′[Pr⁡σ[(σS,σS′)∈E]∣S,S′]≤max⁡S,S′∈ZnPr⁡σ[(σS,σS′)∈E]\begin{aligned} \Pr_{S, S'} [ (S, S') \in \mathcal{E} ] &= \Pr_{S, S', \sigma} [ (\sigma S, \sigma S') \in \mathcal{E} ] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{S, S'} [ \Pr_\sigma [(\sigma S, \sigma S') \in \mathcal{E} ] \mid S, S' ] \\ &\le \max_{S, S' \in \mathcal{Z}^n } \Pr_\sigma [(\sigma S, \sigma S') \in \mathcal{E} ] \end{aligned} S,S′Pr​[(S,S′)∈E]​=S,S′,σPr​[(σS,σS′)∈E]=ES,S′​[σPr​[(σS,σS′)∈E]∣S,S′]≤S,S′∈Znmax​σPr​[(σS,σS′)∈E]​

Replacing E\mathcal{E}E with the set {Z,Z′∈Zn:∃h:∣LZ(h)−LZ′(h)∣≥ϵ2}\{Z, Z' \in \mathcal{Z}^n : \exists h : |L_Z (h) - L_{Z'} (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \}{Z,Z′∈Zn:∃h:∣LZ​(h)−LZ′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​} finishes the proof.

□\square□

Proof of Lemma 2.

Let

S={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)}S = \{ (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ..., (x_n, y_n) \} S={(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)}

and

S′={(x1′,y1′),(x2′,y2′),...,(xn′,yn′)}.S' = \{ (x_1', y_1'), (x_2', y_2'), ..., (x_n', y_n') \}. S′={(x1′​,y1′​),(x2′​,y2′​),...,(xn′​,yn′​)}.

be a pair of fixed sample sets. Define the set C={x1,x2,...,xn,x1′,x2′,...,xn′}⊂X\mathcal{C} = \{ x_1, x_2, ..., x_n, x_1', x_2', ..., x_n' \} \subset \mathcal{X}C={x1​,x2​,...,xn​,x1′​,x2′​,...,xn′​}⊂X (with duplicates removed). The size of C\mathcal{C}C is bounded by 2n2n2n and therefore the size of restriction of H\mathcal{H}H on C\mathcal{C}C is bounded by ΠH(2n)\Pi_\mathcal{H} (2n)ΠH​(2n).

First, fix a hypothesis hhh. For all i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], define ai=∣ℓ(h(xi),yi)−ℓ(h(xi′),yi′)∣≤1a_i = |\ell( h( x_i ), y_i) - \ell( h( x_i' ), y_i' ) | \le 1ai​=∣ℓ(h(xi​),yi​)−ℓ(h(xi′​),yi′​)∣≤1 and let Vi∈{−1,1}V_i \in \{-1, 1\}Vi​∈{−1,1} be a random variable with equal probability:

Pr⁡[Vi=−1]=Pr⁡[Vi=1]=0.5\Pr[ V_i = -1 ] = \Pr[ V_i = 1] = 0.5 Pr[Vi​=−1]=Pr[Vi​=1]=0.5

If we apply a random swap σ\sigmaσ to (S,S′)(S, S')(S,S′), then LσS(hS)−LσS′(hS)L_{ \sigma S} (h_S) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h_S)LσS​(hS​)−LσS′​(hS​) has the same distribution as ∑i∈[n]1naiVi\sum_{i \in [n] } \frac{1}{n} a_i V_i∑i∈[n]​n1​ai​Vi​. Since

E[∑i∈[n]1naiVi]=∑i∈[n]1naiE[Vi]=0,\mathbb{E} \left[ \sum_{i \in [n] } \frac{1}{n} a_i V_i \right] = \sum_{i \in [n] } \frac{1}{n} a_i \mathbb{E}[ V_i ] = 0, E⎣⎢⎡​i∈[n]∑​n1​ai​Vi​⎦⎥⎤​=i∈[n]∑​n1​ai​E[Vi​]=0,

by Hoeffding inequality,

Pr⁡σ[∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2]=Pr⁡[∣∑i∈[n]1naiVi−0∣≥ϵ2]≤2exp⁡(−2∑i∈[n]ai2(nϵ2)2)≤2exp⁡(−n2ϵ22)\begin{aligned} \Pr_\sigma \left[ |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] &= \Pr \left[ \left| \sum_{i \in [n] } \frac{1}{n} a_i V_i - 0 \right| \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] \\ &\le 2 \exp \left( - \frac{ 2 }{ \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i^2 } \left( \frac{n \epsilon}{2} \right)^2 \right) \\ &\le 2 \exp \left( - \frac{n^2 \epsilon^2 }{2} \right) \end{aligned} σPr​[∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]​=Pr⎣⎢⎡​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∈[n]∑​n1​ai​Vi​−0∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​≥2ϵ​⎦⎥⎤​≤2exp(−∑i∈[n]​ai2​2​(2nϵ​)2)≤2exp(−2n2ϵ2​)​

The last inequality follows from that ∑i∈[n]ai2≤n\sum_{i \in [n] } a_i^2 \le n∑i∈[n]​ai2​≤n.

Since for each h∈Hh \in \mathcal{H}h∈H, it has the same behavior on C\mathcal{C}C as some function in HC\mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C}HC​. We can apply union bound on HC\mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C}HC​.

Pr⁡σ[∃h:∣LσS(h)−LσS′(h)∣≥ϵ2]≤2∣HC∣exp⁡(−n2ϵ22)≤2ΠH(2n)exp⁡(−n2ϵ22)\Pr_\sigma \left[ \exists h : |L_{ \sigma S} (h) - L_{ \sigma S' } (h) | \ge \frac{\epsilon}{2} \right] \le 2 |\mathcal{H}_\mathcal{C} | \exp \left( - \frac{n^2 \epsilon^2 }{2} \right) \le 2 \Pi_\mathcal{H} (2n) \exp \left( - \frac{n^2 \epsilon^2 }{2} \right) σPr​[∃h:∣LσS​(h)−LσS′​(h)∣≥2ϵ​]≤2∣HC​∣exp(−2n2ϵ2​)≤2ΠH​(2n)exp(−2n2ϵ2​)

□\square□

Advanced Composition

Posted on 2020-11-13 Edited on 2020-11-15

Once we have designed some basic differentially private algorithms, it is a natural idea to combine them and analysis the privacy loss. We begin with an illustrative example that sets up the mathematical model step by step.

Image yourself in front of the door of a safe vault protected by a password lock. To open the door, you need the correct password PPP. If tried with the wrong password, the lock would destroy itself automatically.

Luckily, you know two candidate passwords P1P_1P1​ and P2P_2P2​, with one of them being the correct one. Further, you notice that the designer of the lock left a collection of boxes near the door, which contain information on how they decide the correct passwords. Obtaining complete information of anyone of them gives you the correct password.

But the boxes are also protected and you don’t have legally access to them. However, you can hack into the boxes. Hacking into the box won’t give you all its information, but a random message. In particular, each box BBB is associated with a set RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​, which is a finite collection of messages (in English). When BBB is hacked, it returns a message YBY_BYB​ generated randomly from RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​, whose distribution depends on the correct password PPP.

Let DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ be the distribution of YBY_BYB​ if the correct password is P1P_1P1​, and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ be the one if the correct password is P2P_2P2​. If there is a huge difference between DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​, then you might be able to guess the correct password.

E.g., suppose RB=\mathcal{R}_B =RB​= { “Dog bites.”, “Cat scratches.” } and the distributions are given as

DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​
“Dog bites.” 0.99 0.01
“Cat scratches.” 0.01 0.99

Hence, when you get YB=Y_B=YB​= “Dog bites.”, you prefer P1P_1P1​ over P2P_2P2​ and vice versa.

Anticipating such potential information leakage, the designer of the lock equips the boxes with a defense mechanism, called (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0)-mechanism. It guarantees the distributions DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ are similar so that it is hard for you to infer the correct password from the message. In particular, ∀S⊂RB\forall S \subset \mathcal{R}_B∀S⊂RB​, if SSS is measurable, it holds that

Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P1]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P2]Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P2]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[YB∈S ∣ P=P1]\Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_1 ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_2 ] \\ \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_2 ] \le e^\epsilon \cdot \Pr[ Y_B \in S \ | \ P = P_1 ] \\ Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P1​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P2​]Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P2​]≤eϵ⋅Pr[YB​∈S ∣ P=P1​]

When these inequalities are satisfied, we say that DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close. The inequalities require DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ to have the same support on RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​. Therefore, throughout our discussion below, we assume that both DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ and DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​ assign positive probability to each element in RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​. Otherwise, we can just replace RB\mathcal{R}_BRB​ with the support of DB,P1\mathcal{D}_{B, P_1}DB,P1​​ (which is also the support of DB,P2\mathcal{D}_{B, P_2}DB,P2​​).

Now, hacking one box is unlikely to help you to guess the correct password. You want to hack more boxes, with the hope that the information combined will assist you. Due to resource limit, you can’t hack all boxes but only a finite number of them. You choose the first box randomly. Then you choose every new box based on the information obtained from the hacked boxes. The figure below shows an example of hacking five boxes.

Suppose that your resource enables you to hack nnn boxes and let Y⃗n=(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)\vec Y_n = (Y_1, Y_2, ..., Y_n)Yn​=(Y1​,Y2​,...,Yn​) be the output messages you obtained. Similar to the situation of hacking one box, if the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​, conditioned on P=P1P = P_1P=P1​, is utterly distant from that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​, then there could be some cases when you can confidently infer the true password. Conversely, to prevent severe information leakage, the designer needs to ensure there isn’t such case, i.e., the two distributions should be similar.

What makes things even more complicated is that, the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ depends not only on the output distributions of the boxes, but also on your strategy of choosing the boxes to hack. Let’s use symbol AAA to denote your strategy. Whatever AAA is, the designer need to guarantee that the distribution of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ conditioned P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ should be similar to that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​.

Surprisingly, this is in some sense achievable, as long as for each box, its output distribution conditioned on P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ is (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close to that conditioned on P=P2P = P_2P=P2​.

Let R\mathcal{R}R be the set of possible possible messages of all boxes.

Theorem. ∀A\forall A∀A, ∀S⊂Rn\forall S \subset \mathcal{R}^n∀S⊂Rn, it holds that ∀δ′∈(0,1)\forall \delta' \in (0, 1)∀δ′∈(0,1),

Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′ \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] \le e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \\ \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] \le e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]≤eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′

where ϵ′=kϵ(eϵ−1)+ϵ2nlog⁡1δ′\epsilon' = k\epsilon(e^\epsilon - 1) + \epsilon \sqrt{2 n \log \frac{1}{\delta'} }ϵ′=kϵ(eϵ−1)+ϵ2nlogδ′1​​.

If we view ϵ\epsilonϵ as the privacy loss of a single box, then the theorem states that the privacy loss grows to O(nϵ)O(\sqrt {n} \epsilon )O(n​ϵ) is nnn boxes are hacked.

To prove the theorem, we need a rigorous model for the problem.

Definitions.

  1. I\mathcal{I}I: the index set.

  2. {Bα:α∈I}\{ B_\alpha : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Bα​:α∈I}: the collection of boxes.

  3. {Rα:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{R}_{\alpha} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Rα​:α∈I}: the ranges of the outputs of the boxes.

  4. R≐∪α∈IRα\mathcal{R} \doteq \cup_{\alpha \in \mathcal{I} } R_\alphaR≐∪α∈I​Rα​: the range of any possible output by any box.

  5. {Dα,P1:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Dα,P1​​:α∈I} ({Dα,P2:α∈I}\{ \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} : \alpha \in \mathcal{I} \}{Dα,P2​​:α∈I}): the set of output distribution when the correct password is P1P_1P1​ (P2P_2P2​). Without loss of generality, we assume that for a fixed α∈I\alpha \in \mathcal{I}α∈I, the distribution Dα,P1\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1}Dα,P1​​ (Dα,P2\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2}Dα,P2​​) assigns positive probability to each element in Rα\mathcal{R}_\alphaRα​. Moreover, Dα,P1\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1}Dα,P1​​ and Dα,P2\mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2}Dα,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close.

  6. nnn: the number of boxes you can hack.

  7. i⃗k≐(i1,i2,...,ik)\vec i_k \doteq (i_1, i_2, ..., i_k)ik​≐(i1​,i2​,...,ik​): the index sequence of boxes you have chosen to hack up to time kkk, where k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n]. When k=0k = 0k=0, i⃗0\vec i_0i0​ corresponds to a empty sequence.

  8. Y⃗k=(Y1,Y2,...,Yk):\vec Y_k = (Y_1, Y_2, ..., Y_k):Yk​=(Y1​,Y2​,...,Yk​): the random variables that represent messages outputted by the chosen boxes up to time k∈[1,n]k \in [1, n]k∈[1,n], where Yt∈Rit⊂RY_t \in \mathcal{R}_{i_t} \subset \mathcal{R}Yt​∈Rit​​⊂R for t∈[1,k]t \in [1, k]t∈[1,k]. Therefore, Y⃗k\vec Y_kYk​ can be view as random vector in Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk.

  9. x⃗k=(x1,x2,...,xk)∈Rk:\vec x_k = (x_1, x_2, ..., x_k) \in \mathcal{R}^k:xk​=(x1​,x2​,...,xk​)∈Rk: a point in Rk\mathcal{R}^kRk, where k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n]. When k=0k = 0k=0, we define x⃗0=∅\vec x_0 = \emptysetx0​=∅.

  10. h⃗k=<i⃗k,x⃗k>=<(i1,i2,i3,...,ik),(x1,x2,...,xk)>:\vec h_k = \left< \vec i_k, \vec x_k \right> = \left< (i_1, i_2, i_3, ..., i_k), (x_1, x_2, ..., x_k) \right>:hk​=⟨ik​,xk​⟩=⟨(i1​,i2​,i3​,...,ik​),(x1​,x2​,...,xk​)⟩: the history up to k∈[0,n]k \in [0, n]k∈[0,n], which consists of the chosen indexes and observations up to time kkk. We use h⃗0\vec h_0h0​ to denote the empty history.

  11. A:A:A: your strategy (policy) for choosing boxes. It works as follows: for any fixed history h⃗k=<i⃗k,x⃗k>\vec h_k = \left< \vec i_k, \vec x_k \right>hk​=⟨ik​,xk​⟩, A is associated with a fixed distribution DA,h⃗k\mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_k}DA,hk​​ over I∖i⃗k\mathcal{I} \setminus \vec i_kI∖ik​, the set of indexes of the unchosen boxes. When inputted with h⃗k\vec h_khk​, AAA returns a random variable A(h⃗k)A(\vec h_k)A(hk​) that follows the distribution DA,h⃗k\mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_k}DA,hk​​.

We will show that, no matter what strategy you use, it is unlikely that you distinguish via the output Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ whether the correct password is P1P_1P1​ or P2P_2P2​. This is because whether P=P1P = P_1P=P1​ or not, the output distributions of Y⃗n\vec Y_nYn​ are similar.

Proof of the theorem. We will just prove the first inequality, and the second one follows from symmetry. We consider a bad set in Rn\mathcal{R}^nRn:

W≐{x⃗n∈Rn:Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]≥eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]}\mathcal{W} \doteq \{ \vec x_n \in \mathcal{R}^n : \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] \ge e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] \} W≐{xn​∈Rn:Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]≥eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]}

and will use the following lemma.

Lemma. Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈W ∣ P=P1,A]≤δ′\Pr[ \vec Y_n \in \mathcal{W}\ | \ P = P_1, A] \le \delta'Pr[Yn​∈W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤δ′.

Hence,

Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P1,A]=Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩W ∣ P=P1,A]≤Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈W ∣ P=P1,A]≤Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′=∑x⃗n∈S∩WˉPr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]+δ′<∑x⃗n∈S∩Wˉeϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′=eϵ′⋅Pr⁡[Y⃗n∈S ∣ P=P2,A]+δ′\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_1, A] &= \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \mathcal{W} \ | \ P = P_1, A] \\ &\le \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in \mathcal{W} \ | \ P = P_1, A] \\ &\le \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' \\ &= \sum_{ \vec x_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } } \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] + \delta' \\ &< \sum_{ \vec x_n \in S \cap \bar{\mathcal{W} } } e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \\ &= e^{\epsilon'} \cdot \Pr[ \vec Y_n \in S \ | \ P = P_2, A] + \delta' \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P1​,A]​=Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+Pr[Yn​∈S∩W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+Pr[Yn​∈W ∣ P=P1​,A]≤Pr[Yn​∈S∩Wˉ ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′=xn​∈S∩Wˉ∑​Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]+δ′<xn​∈S∩Wˉ∑​eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′=eϵ′⋅Pr[Yn​∈S ∣ P=P2​,A]+δ′​

The first inequality follows from monotonicity of probability, the second one from the lemma, and the final one from the definition of W\mathcal{W}W.

Proof of the lemma. To prove the lemma, we need only to consider those point x⃗n\vec x_nxn​ with

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]>0.\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] > 0. Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]>0.

Otherwise, x⃗n\vec x_nxn​ contributes to 0 probability to the set W\mathcal{W}W (whether it belongs to W\mathcal{W}W or not).

Now, we expand the probability Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A]Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]. To obtain the kkk-th output, there are two steps

  1. AAA generates a index iki_kik​ of a box based on the known history h⃗k−1\vec h_{k - 1}hk−1​.
  2. The box BikB_{i_k}Bik​​ is hacked, and output a random message xkx_kxk​ sampled from its distribution Dik,P1D_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​.

Let H⃗k\vec H_kHk​ be a random variable that represents the history up to kkk. By chain rule, we have

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]=∏k=1nPr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]  ⋅∏k=1nPr⁡A(h⃗k−1)∼DA,h⃗k−1[A(h⃗k−1)=ik∣H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] &= \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] \\ &\ \ \cdot \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) \sim \mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_{k - 1} } } [ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k \mid \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]​=k=1∏n​Yk​∼Dik​,P1​​Pr​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]  ⋅k=1∏n​A(hk−1​)∼DA,hk−1​​Pr​[A(hk−1​)=ik​∣Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​

By Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]>0\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] > 0Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]>0, each term in the expansion are positive. Similarly,

Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]=∏k=1nPr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]  ⋅∏k=1nPr⁡A(h⃗k−1)∼DA,h⃗k−1[A(h⃗k−1)=ik∣H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]\begin{aligned} \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] &= \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] \\ &\ \ \cdot \prod_{k = 1}^n \Pr_{ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) \sim \mathcal{D}_{A, \vec h_{k - 1} } } [ A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k \mid \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] \end{aligned} Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]​=k=1∏n​Yk​∼Dik​,P2​​Pr​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]  ⋅k=1∏n​A(hk−1​)∼DA,hk−1​​Pr​[A(hk−1​)=ik​∣Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]​

As both Dik,P1\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​ and Dik,P2\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2}Dik​,P2​​ assign positive probability to each point in Rik\mathcal{R}_{i_k}Rik​​, we know Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]>0\Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] > 0Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]>0.

We are ready to consider the ratio:

ln⁡Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P1,A]Pr⁡[Y⃗n=x⃗n ∣ P=P2,A]=∑k=1nln⁡Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A].\begin{aligned} \ln \frac{ \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_1, A] }{ \Pr[ \vec Y_n = \vec x_n \ | \ P = P_2, A] } = \sum_{k = 1}^n \ln \frac{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] }{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = x_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] }. \end{aligned} lnPr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P2​,A]Pr[Yn​=xn​ ∣ P=P1​,A]​=k=1∑n​lnPrYk​∼Dik​,P2​​​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]PrYk​∼Dik​,P1​​​[Yk​=xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​.​

If we replace xkx_kxk​ by a random variable Xk∼Dik,P1X_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Xk​∼Dik​,P1​​, then

Ck≐ln⁡Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P1[Yk=Xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P1,A]Pr⁡Yk∼Dik,P2[Yk=Xk ∣A(h⃗k−1)=ik,H⃗k−1=h⃗k−1, P=P2,A]C_k \doteq \ln \frac{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1} } [ Y_k = X_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_1, A ] }{ \Pr_{Y_k \sim \mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2} } [ Y_k = X_k \ | A(\vec h_{k - 1} ) = i_k, \vec H_{k - 1} = \vec h_{k - 1}, \ P = P_2, A ] } Ck​≐lnPrYk​∼Dik​,P2​​​[Yk​=Xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P2​,A]PrYk​∼Dik​,P1​​​[Yk​=Xk​ ∣A(hk−1​)=ik​,Hk−1​=hk−1​, P=P1​,A]​

is a random variable. As Dik,P1\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_1}Dik​,P1​​ and Dik,P2\mathcal{D}_{i_k, P_2}Dik​,P2​​ are (ϵ,0)(\epsilon, 0)(ϵ,0) close, we have

Ck≤ϵ.C_k \le \epsilon. Ck​≤ϵ.

Further, we have

Fact 1. For any α∈I\alpha \in \mathcal{I}α∈I, it holds that

EX∼Dα,P1[ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=X]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=X]]=∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]≤∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]+∑x∈RαPr⁡X∼Dα,P2[X=x]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]=∑x∈Rα[Pr⁡X∼Dα,P1[X=x]−Pr⁡X∼Dα,P2[X=x]]⋅ln⁡Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P1[Y=x]Pr⁡Y∼Dα,P2[Y=x]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} } \left[ \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = X] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = X] } \right] &= \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &\le \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &+ \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &= \sum_{x \in \mathcal{R}_\alpha } \left[ \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] - \underset{ X \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ X = x] \right] \cdot \ln \frac{ \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_1} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } { \underset{ Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\alpha, P_2} }{ \Pr } [ Y = x] } \\ &\le (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilon \end{aligned} EX∼Dα,P1​​​⎣⎢⎡​lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=X]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=X]​⎦⎥⎤​​=x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​≤x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​+x∈Rα​∑​X∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[X=x]⋅lnY∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]​=x∈Rα​∑​[X∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[X=x]−X∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[X=x]]⋅lnY∼Dα,P2​​Pr​[Y=x]Y∼Dα,P1​​Pr​[Y=x]​≤(eϵ−1)ϵ​

Therefore, E[Ck]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ\mathbb{E} [C_k] \le (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilonE[Ck​]≤(eϵ−1)ϵ.

Fact 2. (Azuma Inequality). Let C1,....,CnC_1, ...., C_nC1​,....,Cn​ be random variables such that ∀k∈[n]\forall k \in [n]∀k∈[n], Pr⁡[∣Ck∣≤ϵ]=1\Pr[ |C_k| \le \epsilon ] = 1Pr[∣Ck​∣≤ϵ]=1, and for every (c1,...,ck−1)∈Supp(C1,...,Ck−1)(c_1, ..., c_{k -1} ) \in \text{Supp} (C_1, ..., C_{k - 1} )(c1​,...,ck−1​)∈Supp(C1​,...,Ck−1​), we have

E[Ci∣C1=c1,...,Ck−1=ck−1]≤β,\mathbb{E}[ C_i \mid C_1 = c_1, ..., C_{k -1} = c_{k - 1} ] \le \beta, E[Ci​∣C1​=c1​,...,Ck−1​=ck−1​]≤β,

Then for every z>0z > 0z>0, we have

Pr⁡[∑k=1nCi−nβ>z]≤exp⁡(−z22nϵ2)\Pr[ \sum_{k = 1}^n C_i - n \beta > z] \le \exp(- \frac{z^2}{ 2 n\epsilon^2 } ) Pr[k=1∑n​Ci​−nβ>z]≤exp(−2nϵ2z2​)

Finally, applying Azuma Inequality with z=2nlog⁡1δ′z = \sqrt{ 2n \log \frac{1}{\delta'} }z=2nlogδ′1​​ and β=(eϵ−1)ϵ\beta = (e^\epsilon - 1) \epsilonβ=(eϵ−1)ϵ, we get the desired result.

■\blacksquare■

Reference.
